chapters.name: What Is Machine Learning?
topics: What does it mean for a computer to 'learn' — and how is that different from being programmed?
How does machine learning differ from traditional software — where a programmer writes explicit rules?
What is the basic cycle of machine learning: data in, pattern found, prediction out?
Why is machine learning sometimes called 'software 2.0' — and what does that metaphor capture?
What kinds of problems is machine learning good at solving — and what kinds is it bad at?
Why has machine learning become dominant now — what changed in data, hardware, and algorithms?
What does a non-technical person need to understand about machine learning to be an informed citizen?

chapters.name: Data, Patterns, and Generalization
topics: What is training data — and why is it the raw material of machine learning?
How does a machine learning system find patterns in data — and what does 'pattern' mean in this context?
What is generalization — and why is it the goal of every machine learning system?
What is the difference between memorizing data and learning from it?
How does the size of a dataset affect what a model can learn?
What happens when training data is unrepresentative, biased, or incomplete?
Why is data cleaning and preparation often the hardest and most important part of machine learning?

chapters.name: Supervised Learning: Learning from Examples
topics: What is supervised learning — and why is it the most common type of machine learning?
How does a supervised model learn to predict outputs from labeled examples?
What are classification and regression — the two main types of supervised learning tasks?
How is spam filtering an example of supervised learning — and what makes it work?
What are labels — who creates them, how accurate are they, and why do they matter?
What are the limitations of supervised learning — and when does it break down?
How does the quality and quantity of labeled examples determine how well a model performs?

chapters.name: Unsupervised Learning: Finding Hidden Structure
topics: What is unsupervised learning — and how does it work without labeled examples?
How does clustering work — grouping similar data points without being told what the groups should be?
What is dimensionality reduction — and why is simplifying complex data useful?
How is unsupervised learning used in customer segmentation, anomaly detection, and recommendation systems?
What are the challenges of unsupervised learning — how do you know if the patterns it finds are meaningful?
How does unsupervised learning relate to how humans learn — finding patterns without being taught?
Why is unsupervised learning important for discovering things that humans haven't thought to look for?

chapters.name: Reinforcement Learning: Learning by Doing
topics: What is reinforcement learning — and how does it learn through trial, error, and reward?
How did reinforcement learning enable AI to master games like chess, Go, and Atari?
What are rewards and penalties in reinforcement learning — and who defines them?
How is reinforcement learning used in robotics, autonomous vehicles, and resource management?
What is RLHF (reinforcement learning from human feedback) — and why is it central to modern chatbots?
What are the risks of reinforcement learning — what happens when the reward signal is poorly designed?
Why is reinforcement learning considered the closest analogy to how animals and humans learn?

chapters.name: Training, Testing, and Validation
topics: What is the training process — and how does a model improve over many iterations?
Why do you split data into training, validation, and test sets — and what does each do?
What is overfitting — and why is a model that performs perfectly on training data often useless in the real world?
What is underfitting — and how do you know when a model hasn't learned enough?
How do you evaluate whether a model is actually good — accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 scores?
What is cross-validation — and why is it a more reliable way to test model performance?
Why is the gap between lab performance and real-world performance one of the biggest problems in machine learning?

chapters.name: Features, Representations, and Embeddings
topics: What are features — and why does choosing the right features determine whether a model succeeds or fails?
How did traditional machine learning require humans to hand-engineer features — and why was that a bottleneck?
What is feature engineering — and why was it once considered the most important skill in machine learning?
How do modern deep learning systems learn their own features — and why was that a breakthrough?
What are embeddings — and how do they represent words, images, or concepts as numbers?
Why do word embeddings capture relationships like 'king is to queen as man is to woman'?
How do representations shape what a model can see and what it's blind to?

chapters.name: Why More Data Often Beats Clever Algorithms
topics: Why did researchers discover that bigger datasets often matter more than better algorithms?
What is the 'unreasonable effectiveness of data' — and what does it mean for machine learning?
How did the explosion of internet data — text, images, video — change what machine learning could accomplish?
What is the relationship between dataset size and model size — and why do they need to scale together?
What are the limits of the 'more data' approach — when does more data stop helping?
How does the availability of data create advantages for large companies — and disadvantages for everyone else?
What does the data hunger of modern AI mean for privacy, copyright, and consent?

chapters.name: Bias in Machine Learning
topics: How does bias enter machine learning systems — through data, labels, algorithms, or deployment?
What are real-world examples of ML bias — in hiring, criminal justice, lending, and healthcare?
Why can a model be mathematically accurate and still be discriminatory?
What is the difference between statistical bias and social bias — and why do both matter?
How do biased datasets reflect and amplify existing inequalities in society?
What techniques exist to detect and reduce bias — and why is none of them a complete solution?
Who is responsible for bias in machine learning — the data collectors, the engineers, or the companies that deploy it?

chapters.name: The Black Box Problem
topics: What does it mean to call a machine learning model a 'black box' — and why is that a problem?
Why can't most deep learning models explain how they reached their conclusions?
What is explainable AI (XAI) — and how does it try to make model decisions interpretable?
When does the black box problem matter most — in medicine, law, finance, and criminal justice?
What is the tradeoff between model accuracy and model interpretability?
How do regulators and courts handle decisions made by systems no one can fully explain?
Should AI systems be required to explain their reasoning — and who should set that requirement?

chapters.name: How Machine Learning Is Evaluated
topics: What are benchmarks — and how do researchers use them to compare machine learning models?
Why can a model score well on benchmarks and still fail in real-world applications?
What is the difference between accuracy, precision, recall, and false positive/false negative rates?
How do leaderboards and competitions shape what gets built — and what gets ignored?
What is benchmark gaming — and how do some models optimize for tests rather than real performance?
How should a non-technical person interpret claims about AI performance?
Why is measuring what matters harder than measuring what's easy — and how does that distort ML research?

chapters.name: Machine Learning in Your Life
topics: Where is machine learning already making decisions that affect you — even if you don't know it?
How does ML power the content you see on social media, the ads you receive, and the search results you get?
How is ML used in credit scoring, insurance pricing, and job application screening?
What does it mean when ML is used in healthcare diagnostics — and should patients know?
How does ML affect your experience of shopping, streaming, navigation, and communication?
What questions should you ask when you discover ML is involved in a decision about you?
Why does understanding machine learning help you navigate the modern world more effectively?
